At first fate favoured the latter, who extended his conquests on every side, captured Mecca in 1803, Madina in the following year, and the territory of Oman soon after, sacked the sacred city of Kerbela on the borders of Mesopotamia, raided Basra and Damascus, and in short brought under his sway practically the whole of Arabia. But the Turks persevered ; Saud III. died, his successor, Abdul Aziz IL, was assassinated and the throne of Najd fell to Abdullah, whose dilatory tactics in face ol Muhammad Ali, Pasha of Egypt,- and his sons, resulted in the dramatic collapse of the great empire which he had inherited. In 1818 a.d ., Ibrahim Pasha captured the Wahhabi capital, Daraiyya, after a four months' siege, massacred many members of the royal family, and the religious luminaries of the Wahhabi sect, and sent Abdullah himself in chains to Egypt, where he was executed. For the next 30 years Central Arabia had a sufficient experience of Turkish rule ; at frequent intervals revolts headed by members of the Ibn Saud family, which had escaped the massacre of Daraiyya, met with a greater or less measure of success, but Najd did not recover its complete independence until Faisal, the grandson of Abdullah, escaped from Cairo and recovered the throne between 1840 and 1850 a.d. Najd now enjoyed a period of comparative peace, but on the death of Faisal about 1869, his two eldest sons, Abdullah and Saud, plunged the country into civil strife in their struggle for the throne. Each occupied it in turn for short periods and Abdullah invited the assistance of the comparatively new dynasty of Ibn Rashid in a final effort to establish himself permanently on the throne ; but he reckoned without his host, for Muhammad Ibn Rashid, having defeated and slain Saud, deposed his ally Abdullah and took the throne of Najd for himself. For a decade or more the Ibn Sand dynasty lay dormant, while its surviving remnants lived in exile at Bahrain and Kuwait rather than serve a foreign ruler in their own territories. Abdullah had left no children, but Saud had left a considerable family, and a third son of Faisal, by name Abdul Rahman, survived to live.in retire ment at Kuwait with a large family of growing boys. mods.abstract: This note gives a very short history of Central Arabia in thirteen paragraphs. Details are given concerning the history of Nejd [Najd], the rise and spread of the Wahhabi movement, and the Āl Sa‘ūd family and their relations with their neighbours, including the Āl Rashīd family, the Hashemite rulers of the Hejaz, Oman and the Ottoman Empire, as well as Britain. Further details are given concerning the ruler Imam Abdul Aziz Ibn Abdul Rahman Ibn Faisal Ibn Saud [‘Abd al-‘Azīz bin ‘Abd al-Raḥmān bin Fayṣal Āl Sa‘ūd] and the signing of a treaty between him and Sir Percy Zachariah Cox in 1916.
